Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis of the Mammalian Olfactory Code
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project was developed during a NSF Ideas Lab on "Cracking the Olfactory Code" and is jointly funded by the Chemistry of Life Processes program in the Chemistry Division, the Mathematical Biology program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences, the Physics of Living Systems program in the Physics Division, the Neural Systems Cluster in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, the Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Division of Emerging Frontiers.

The mammalian sense of smell is arguably the most complex sensory system in the animal kingdom. Hundreds of olfactory receptors are deployed to detect a vast array of chemicals with exquisite sensitivity in complex environments. This collaborative project combines biochemistry, neurobiology, genomics, mathematics and new technologies to understand how the mammalian olfactory system detects, encodes and extracts meaning from chemical stimuli. The goals of this project are to: (1) elucidate fundamental neural mechanisms for how chemical sensation turns into the perception of a smell; (2) produce a vast array of scientific resources to olfactory scientists; (3) provide valuable information for broader audiences, including for molecular evolution, chemical ecology, and flavor and fragrance communities; (4) establish new technologies and mathematical frameworks to study biological systems; and (5) facilitate applied chemical sensing technologies for environmental monitoring, food safety, and homeland security. The project also offers training opportunities from the high school to the postdoctoral trainee level, and educational opportunities and outreach through partnerships with local science museums as well as science learning centers and their media outlets.

This project's efforts are organized around three aims that focus on how information about odor identity and odor valence (attractiveness/aversiveness) is encoded at the level of olfactory receptors (Aim 1); within the olfactory bulb, where odor information is first processed (Aim 2); and the cortical amygdala, where odor codes may integrate with other information streams (Aim 3). Completion of the project entails the development and use a broad array of innovative approaches that include mapping all human and mouse odorant receptors to the chemicals they bind, defining the innate valence of these chemicals using behavioral assays, mapping all odorant receptor projections to the olfactory bulb, functionally characterizing their neural representations in the olfactory bulb and cortical amygdala, and using novel mathematical approaches to understand the underlying structure of odor coding and olfactory neural circuits at the level of sensory neurons, olfactory bulb glomeruli, and amygdala. Progress towards each aim involves close collaborations between team members with diverse expertise, including molecular biology, behavioral neuroscience, in vivo functional imaging, and mathematical and theoretical analysis of complex datasets. The multidisciplinary strategy implemented here promises to lead to an integrated and comprehensive understanding of how mammals sense and make sense of their chemical environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the entire IDEAS Lab project were to understand how the mammalian olfactory system detects, encodes and extracts meaning from olfactory stimuli. The sub goals of our laboratory are to determine the features of sensory information encoded in the mouse OB, and to determine how the code for odor information among sensory neurons is transformed by processing in the olfactory bulb into a code at the level of olfactory bulb output neurons.

We made substantial progress on these goals over the funding period.  First, using a novel olfactometer design which has been shared via publications and exchange of design files, we generated maps of olfactory bulb odor responses to over 200 odorants; these data in effect form a comprehensive 'atlas' of odor representations and the locations of glomeruli that are most sensitive to these odorants. This dataset is being prepared for publication and will be a major resource for the field of olfactory neuroscience. These datasets have also served as the foundation for the computational analyses of odor representations that are being performed by the Itskov and Magnasco labs. This work is ongoing. Second, in collaboration with the Matsunami lab, we developed a pipeline for linking odorant receptors and their odorant ligands to glomeruli of the olfactory bulb. We validated this pipeline using two odorant receptors with previously-unknown odorant ligands and unknown location in the olfactory bulb; we generated two new mouse lines with fluorescent-tagged glomeruli for each odorant receptor, and used these to characterize their odorant response spectra in vivo.   An expansion of this pipeline is still in progress, and we expect to be able to link odorant receptor identity to particular glomeruli with well-characterized odorant response properties for a large fraction of glomeruli across the dorsal olfactory bulb. Third, we developed approaches for simultaneous imaging of olfactory sensory inputs and mitral/tufted cell outputs from olfactory bulb glomeruli, using cell-type specific mouse strains and both green and red genetically-encoded calcium reporters. This approach represents an advance over the originally-proposed work, and allows us to compare input and output representations much more precisely. This work is also ongoing, and will leverage the knowledge gained from the comprehensive odor mapping, as well as the computational analyses done in collaboration with the Itskov lab. An overview of these outcomes is shown in the accompanying Figure 1.

                In terms of broader impacts from this project, the novel olfactometer design and the odor map 'atlas' are expected to have a significant impact in advancing discovery among olfactory neuroscientists. We have so far shared the olfactometer design with a number of laboratories around the world, including other IDEASLab investigators, in addition to publishing the characterization of the device. We are currently curating the odorant response map atlas, and have developed custom software to aid in visualization and browsing of the maps, which we will share via a publically-accessible portal.  To disseminate progress from the broader IDEAS Lab project, I co-organized a full-day special symposium at the 2019 Annual meeting of the Association for Chemoreception Sciences, which included talks from other IDEAS Lab investigators as well as other investigators doing related work in the chemical senses; this symposium was well-attended and a highlight of the meeting.

                The project has also provided training opportunities for postdoctoral and undergraduate researchers. Two bioengineering undergraduates (one female) worked on developing the novel olfactometer as part of their senior project, participated in the university's UROP fellowship program and were coauthors on the paper describing this device. A third female undergraduate began working on the odorant mapping and receptor identification pipeline project last year, and will be a coauthor on the paper describing this work. The postdoctoral associate acquired training in in vivo imaging and data analysis while working on this project; he subsequently received a BRAIN Initiative F32 NRSA award, and is now a Research Assistant Professor at University of Pittsburgh
